questions.clue: This early 20th-century movement, exemplified by Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque, is known for its abstract approach and geometric shapes.
Originating in Switzerland during World War I, this avant-garde movement embraced absurdity and a rejection of traditional values.
Characterized by vibrant colors and dream-like scenes, this movement sought to depict the unconscious mind, with Salvador Dalí as a famous example.
Founded in Germany in 1919, this movement aimed to reunite creativity and manufacturing, promoting designs that were both functional and beautiful.
Known for its minimalist approach and use of new materials, this mid-20th-century movement also embraced elements of chance in its creative process; Jackson Pollock was a prominent figure.

categories.name: Culinary Techniques from Around the World

questions.clue: This French term refers to cutting vegetables into thin strips or matchsticks.
A staple in Japanese cuisine, this technique involves quickly cooking vegetables and meat in a small amount of hot oil.
In Italy, this delightful technique involves lightly deep-frying and includes foods like arancini and calamari.
This Chinese technique, known as velveting, involves marinating meat in a mixture including egg white and cornstarch before stir-frying.
Developed in Peru, this raw fish technique uses citrus juices to denature proteins, resulting in a dish called ceviche.
This Greek hero fought in the Trojan War and is known for his heel.
According to Norse mythology, this hammer-wielding god is a son of Odin.
In Roman mythology, she is the queen of the gods and the wife of Jupiter.
The Egyptian god Anubis is often depicted with the head of this animal.
In the Hindu epic Mahabharata, this prince is portrayed as the main protagonist of the Bhagavad Gita.
This scientist proposed the theory of relativity, transforming our understanding of space and time.
This English naturalist outlined the concept of natural selection in 'On the Origin of Species'.
This pioneer of alternating current (AC) electricity was the namesake for the SI unit of magnetic flux density.
This Polish-born physicist and chemist was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and the only person to win in two different scientific fields.
This German mathematician and astronomer was a key figure in the Scientific Revolution, known for his laws of planetary motion.
This 1954 U.S. Supreme Court decision declared racial segregation in public schools unconstitutional.
In 1966, this case established the practice of issuing warnings about rights to criminal suspects, known as the 'Miranda Rights.'
This 1973 decision by the U.S. Supreme Court protected a woman's liberty to choose to have an abortion without excessive government restriction.
The 1803 case that established the principle of judicial review, giving the Supreme Court the power to declare acts of Congress unconstitutional.
This 1896 case upheld the constitutionality of racial segregation under the 'separate but equal' doctrine, later overturned by Brown v. Board of Education.

final.clue: Though often remembered for another genre, this author's work 'North and South' provides a critical depiction of class and industry in Victorian England.
